user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_seek_:
```c
static int lfs_dir_seek_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, lfs_off_t off) {
    // simply walk from head dir
    int err = lfs_dir_rewind_(lfs, dir);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // first two for ./..
    dir->pos = lfs_min(2, off);
    off -= dir->pos;

    // skip superblock entry
    dir->id = (off > 0 && lfs_pair_cmp(dir->head, lfs->root) == 0);

    while (off > 0) {
        if (dir->id == dir->m.count) {
            if (!dir->m.split) {
                return LFS_ERR_INVAL;
            }

            err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->m.tail);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            dir->id = 0;
        }

        int diff = lfs_min(dir->m.count - dir->id, off);
        dir->id += diff;
        dir->pos += diff;
        off -= diff;
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->m.tail);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.14 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment calls a project function lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->m.tail) and does not use the standard library function memcmp. The only comparator seen in the surrounding code is lfs_pair_cmp (a user-defined function). This fragment itself therefore does not violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14. (Note: if lfs_dir_fetch or other called functions internally used memcmp to compare null‑terminated strings, that internal use would violate the rule, but that is not visible in this fragment.)
